results.title: The Tailor from Torzhok
results.creator_credit: Yakov Protazanov, Mezhrabpom-Russ and Valentin Turkin
results.brief_description:
A simple tailor from a rural village unexpectedly strikes it rich in Leningrad in this fast paced satirical comedy which was commissioned to publicise the state lottery. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Yakov Protazanov ; script, V. Turkin ; photography, P. Yermolov.
Cast: L. Deikun, I. Ilyinsky.

results.title: Arsenal
results.brief_description:
Revolution in the Ukraine in 1917-19, culminating in the suppression of the workers’ revolt in a munition factory at Kiev, is treated symbolically, employing the dynamics of montage in an epic celebration of victory in defeat. A blend of folklore, comedy, drama and caricature. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writers, Isaac Shpinel, Vladimir Muller ; photography, Daniel Demutski.
Cast: Semyon Svashenko, Mikola Nademsky, Ambrose Buchma, Pyotr Masokha.

results.title: The Phantom of the opera
results.creator_credit: Edward Sedgwick, Rupert Julian, Carl Laemmle and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description:
In his most famous role as Erik the Phantom, Chaney demonstrated his genius for mime, and his ability to bring humanity to the most deformed of creatures. Produced by Universal, the film was shot in 1923 and shelved for nearly two years, and was subjected to intensive studio tinkering. It was both the stepping off point for Chaney’s run as a superstar at M.G.M. and the prototype for the horror film cycle at Universal in the 1930s. The story concerns Erik, a much-feared fiend who haunts the Paris Opera House. Lurking around the damp, dank passages deep in the cellars of the theater, he secretly coaches understudy Christine Daae to be an opera star. Through a startling sequence of terrors, including sending a giant chandelier crashing down on the opera patrons, the chandelier crashing down on the opera patrons, the Phantom forces the lead soprano to withdraw from the opera, permitting Christine to step in. Luring Christine into his subterranean lair below the opera house, the Phantom confesses his love. Alternative versions also available on 16mm film and VHS.

Credits: Producer, Carl Laemmle ; directors, Rupert Julian, Edward Sedgwick ; writers, Raymond Shrock, Elliot Clawson ; photography, Charles Van Enger, Virgil Miller, Milton Bridenbecker ; art director, Dan Hall.
Cast: Lon Chaney, Mary Philbin, Norman Kerry, Gibson Gowland.

results.title: Intolerance
results.brief_description:
Griffith used a variety of tinted film stock for dramatic effect on a scale seldom equalled in silent cinema. One of the most influential films in the history of cinema, on the theme of man’s intolerance throughout the ages, told in four separate but interwoven stories—’Fall of Babylon’, ‘Passion of Christ’, ‘Massacre of St. Bartholomew’ and ‘The mother and the law’—which culminate in a climax of cross cutting. Alternate versions also available on 16mm and VHS.
Credits: Director, writer, D. W. Griffith ; photography, G. W. Bitzer ; production designer, Frank “Huck” Wortman ; music, Joseph Carl Breil, D.W. Griffith ; editor, James Smith, Rose Smith.
Cast: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh, Robert Harron, Miriam Cooper, Walter Long, Tully Marshall.

results.title: The Birth of a nation
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith, D W Griffith Productions and Frank Woods
results.brief_description:
This epic Civil War drama portrays life in the South during and after the Civil War. The film derives its emotional power from its moving constantly from the large drama to intimate human stories, in particular the war’s effects on a Northern family (the Stonemans) and its Southern counterpart (the Camerons). It is one of the most influential films in the history of the cinema and, because of its racism, one of the most controversial. Also available on 35mm and VHS. Other versions also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producer, director, D.W. Griffith ; writers, D.W. Griffith, Frank E. Woods ; photography, G.W. Bitzer.
Cast: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh, Henry Walthall, Ralph Lewis.

results.title: Melancholia
results.creator_credit: Andi Engel, Colin MacCabe and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
An existential political thriller that grapples with the legacy of post-1968 European political activism. A successful but angst ridden German art critic, established in London, is contacted by a student friend from the 1960s to assassinate a Chilean military torturer. Approaching a comfortable middle age, he is unsettled by the disruption which forces him to confront his political convictions and choose between the activism of his youth or the complacency and security of his present life. Filmed on location in London and Hamburg.

Credits: Producer, Colin McCabe ; director, Andi Engel ; writer, Andi Engel, Lewis Rodia ; phototography, Denis Crossan ; editing, Christopher Roth ; music, Simon Fisher Turner.
Cast: Jeroen Krabbe, Susannah York, Ulrich Wildgruber, Kate Hardie.

results.title: The Sailor's return
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, Otto Plaschkes, Ariel Productions and Euston Films
results.brief_description:
Set in the mid-19th century, this is the story of a sailor who returns to England with a black bride, an African princess, and sets up business as an innkeeper with her dowry. Before long they encounter racial prejudice from family and neighbours, which quickly reaches hysterical proportions with tragic results. Although the film features a strong performance from Tom Bell and an impressive re-creation of ‘unspoiled’ English village life, its treatment of racism is naive and confused, lacking historical context, especially in relation to the British imperialism that shaped British society in the 19th century.

Credits:Producer, Otto Plaschkes ; director, Jack Gold ; writer, James Saunders ; photography, Brian Trufano ; editing, Michael Taylor ; music, Carl Davis.
Cast: Tom Bell, Shope Shodeinde, Mick Ford, Paola Dionisotti, George Costigan.

results.title: Sladke hry minuleho leta = Sweet games of last summer
results.brief_description:
This impressionistic adaptation of De Maupassant’s classic novel ‘Mouche’ about a laundress and her five suitors was made for Czech television. Slovak-born director Juraj Herz has a career in film and television that spans more than 35 years and 30 films, working mainly in Prague but also in Slovakia, Germany and France. Although he first came to prominence in the 1960s, his work stands apart from that of other Czech and Slovak New Wave directors in its willingness to cross genres and constitutes a dense exploration of the fantastic.

Credits: Director, Juraj Herz ; photography, Jozef Simoncic.
Cast: Jana Plichtova, Frantisek Velecky, Peter Debnar, Milan Lasica, Julius Satinsky and Lubor Zahon.

results.title: Ankur = The Seedling
results.creator_credit: Shyam Benegal, Freni Variava, Mohan Bijlani and Blaze Film Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Benegal’s first feature, based on his own story, is a subtlely nuanced exploration of the interrelationship between power, ritual, sexuality and violence. The milieu of feudal society in South India is carefully established as the setting for the playing out of power relations in the liaison between the temporarily abandoned wife of a deaf-mute farmhand and the landlord’s son sent to manage the farm. For the son, sexual attraction is linked to the woman’s lack of social status. Yet he is initially restrained by his middle class fear of exposure. From a position of relative anonymity the woman develops a complex response to the son’s presumption.

Credits: Producers, Mohan J. Bijlani, Freni M. Variava ; director, writer, Shyam Benegal ; photography, Govind Nihalani ; music, Vanraj Bhatia.
Cast: Shabana Azmi, Sadhu Meher, Anant Nag, Priya Tendulkar.
